newsitem.title: UK: London gold and silver ease slightly in PM.
newsitem.headline: London gold and silver ease slightly in PM.

text.p: Gold and silver prices eased gently on Wednesday afternoon following a brisk shortcovering rally earlier in the day, dealers said.
The platinum group metals, however, held on to gains made over the past couple of days on shortcovering.
Bullion fixed at $382.40 an ounce, compared to $383.25 in the morning and $382.30 on Thursday afternoon. Bids were quoted so far between $383.80 and $381.90.
Comex gold was down $0.30 at $385.40 an ounce.
"There was some good shortcovering this morning and then probably some profit taking," a dealer said.
The price movements were sparked by fresh comments regarding the International Monetary Fund's proposal to sell some gold reserves to pay for aid to poor countries, dealers said.

U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin was reported saying in a newspaper interview that the IMF would "ultimately" sell some gold. But Germany's finance state secretary Juergen Stark said in another interview that Germany remained opposed to the sales.
"The IMF had it bouncing around a bit," a dealer said.
Gold prices were unlikely, however, to stray far from the centre of the $380-$385 price band ahead of the over-the-counter options expiry on Thursday afternoon, dealers said.
A mild boost from the Fed's Tuesday decision not to increase interest rates was effectively erased by Wednesday afternoon.
A rate hike would have raised the cost of holding gold, making it less appealing to investors.
Silver was indicated at $4.91/$4.93, up three cents from Tuesday's London close. It was considered more vulnerable to a sell-off than gold after last week's tumble below $5.00.
But until the market saw a major move, it was stuck in a $4.88-$4.94 range, analysts said.
Shortcovering gave a sizable corrective boost to palladium, which was indicated up $2.00 at $119.00/$120.00.
But as long as it remained below the key $120 area it remained susceptible to further sell-offs which pushed it to three-year lows last week, dealers said.
Platinum was also perkier at $387.50/$388.50, up $1.40 from Tuesday's London close.
But analysts said it was likely to remain stuck in a $385-$390 range in the absence of technical and fundamental factors.
